claim: “We indicated 23 years ago — in our 1994 Nature article — that climate models had the atmosphere’s sensitivity to CO2 much too high,” Christy said in a statement.
evidences: [{'evidence_id': 'Climate sensitivity:51', 'evidence_label': 'SUPPORTS', 'article': 'Climate sensitivity', 'evidence': 'The sensitivity of temperature to atmospheric gasses, most notably CO 2, is often expressed in terms of the change in temperature per doubling of the concentration of the gas.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'SUPPORTS', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Climate sensitivity:53', 'evidence_label': 'SUPPORTS', 'article': 'Climate sensitivity', 'evidence': 'In his first paper on the matter, he estimated that global temperature would rise by around 5 to 6\xa0°C (9.0 to 10.8\xa0°F) if the quantity of CO 2 was doubled.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'SUPPORTS', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Climate sensitivity:58', 'evidence_label': 'SUPPORTS', 'article': 'Climate sensitivity', 'evidence': 'For constant humidity they computed a climate sensitivity of 2.3\xa0°C per doubling of CO2 (which they rounded to 2, the value most often quoted from their work, in the abstract of the paper).', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'SUPPORTS', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Global warming controversy:207', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Global warming controversy', 'evidence': 'As defined by the IPCC, climate sensitivity is the "equilibrium temperature rise that would occur for a doubling of CO 2 concentration above pre-industrial levels".', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'James Hansen:126', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'James Hansen', 'evidence': 'They did note that the agreement between the observations and the intermediate scenario was accidental because the climate sensitivity used was higher than current estimates.', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}]
rationale: Asserts climate models overstate atmospheric CO2 sensitivity, thus disputing the extent of modeled global warming

claim: "[T]he influence of  so-called greenhouse gases on near-surface temperature - is not yet  absolutely proven.
evidences: [{'evidence_id': 'Global warming:1270', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Global warming', 'evidence': '"The artificial production of carbon dioxide and its influence on temperature".', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Global warming:276', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Global warming', 'evidence': 'In the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Global warming:55', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Global warming', 'evidence': 'Before the Industrial Revolution, naturally occurring amounts of greenhouse gases caused the air near the surface to be warmer by about 33\xa0°C (59\xa0°F) than it would be in their absence.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Greenhouse effect:76', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Greenhouse effect', 'evidence': 'The presence of N2, CH4, and H2 in the atmosphere contribute to a greenhouse effect, increasing the surface temperature by 21K over the expected temperature of the body with no atmosphere.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Greenhouse gas:310', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Greenhouse gas', 'evidence': 'During the late 20th century, a scientific consensus evolved that increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere cause a substantial rise in global temperatures and changes to other parts of the climate system, with consequences for the environment and for human health.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}]
rationale: Asserts that greenhouse gas influence on near-surface temperature is not proven, disputing the established cause of recent warming.

claim: Thanks to a rapid rebound in recent months, global sea ice levels now equal those seen 29 years ago, when the year 1979 also drew to a close.
evidences: [{'evidence_id': 'Glacier:252', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Glacier', 'evidence': 'This post-glacial rebound, which proceeds very slowly after the melting of the ice sheet or glacier, is currently occurring in measurable amounts in Scandinavia and the Great Lakes region of North America.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Ice age:249', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Ice age', 'evidence': "Due to the high viscosity of the Earth's mantle, the flow of mantle rocks which controls the rebound process is very slow—at a rate of about 1\xa0cm/year near the center of rebound area today.", 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Post-glacial rebound:111', 'evidence_label': 'SUPPORTS', 'article': 'Post-glacial rebound', 'evidence': 'Unusually rapid (up to 4.1 cm/year) present glacial isostatic rebound due to recent ice mass losses in the Amundsen Sea embayment region of Antarctica coupled with low regional mantle viscosity is predicted to provide a modest stabilizing influence on marine ice sheet instability in West Antarctica, but likely not to a sufficient degree to arrest it.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'SUPPORTS', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Post-glacial rebound:48', 'evidence_label': 'SUPPORTS', 'article': 'Post-glacial rebound', 'evidence': 'Thus global sea level fell during glaciation.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'SUPPORTS', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Post-glacial rebound:99', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Post-glacial rebound', 'evidence': 'Recent global warming has caused mountain glaciers and the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica to melt and global sea level to rise.', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['SUPPORTS', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}]
rationale: Asserts long-term sea ice levels are unchanged (now equal to 29 years ago), which disputes evidence of ongoing warming-related ice loss.

rationale: Questions or challenges the idea that recent global warming increased heat-wave severity by pointing to a less severe 2014 event versus 1972, implying doubt about warming's effects.

claim: unadjusted data suggests that temperatures in Australia have only increased by 0.3 degrees over the past century, not the 1 degree usually claimed.
evidences: [{'evidence_id': 'Australia:1011', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Australia', 'evidence': '"Australia\'s extreme heat is sign of things to come, scientists warn".', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Australia:136', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Australia', 'evidence': 'According to the Bureau of Meteorology\'s 2011 Australian Climate Statement, Australia had lower than average temperatures in 2011 as a consequence of a La Niña weather pattern; however, "the country\'s 10-year average continues to demonstrate the rising trend in temperatures, with 2002–2011 likely to rank in the top two warmest 10-year periods on record for Australia, at 0.52\xa0°C (0.94\xa0°F) above the long-term average".', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Australia:137', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Australia', 'evidence': "Furthermore, 2014 was Australia's third warmest year since national temperature observations commenced in 1910.", 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Australia:141', 'evidence_label': 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', 'article': 'Australia', 'evidence': 'January 2019 was the hottest month ever in Australia with average temperatures exceeding 30\xa0°C (86\xa0°F).', 'entropy': 0.6931471805599453, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'NOT_ENOUGH_INFO', None, None, None]}, {'evidence_id': 'Australia:226', 'evidence_label': 'REFUTES', 'article': 'Australia', 'evidence': 'Australia has grown at an average annual rate of 3.6% for over 15 years, in comparison to the OECD annual average of 2.5%.', 'entropy': 0.0, 'votes': ['REFUTES', 'REFUTES', None, None, None]}]
rationale: Disputes the magnitude of observed warming by claiming temperatures rose only 0.3°C in Australia rather than the commonly cited ~1°C, minimizing reported warming.
